> what‚Äôs the purpose of adopting a protocol if we as the dev community are lenient wrt implementation?
Is this in reference to maintaining support for the old versions like 64/63? Or maybe better said, that we're taking into consideration that lots of clients are still on old versions?

author: vorot93
content: Yes, and to excuses for not adopting already agreed upon protocols

author: pipermerriam
content:
Still probably a function of Geth being the 5000 pound gorilla.  It defines the network for the most part and so if it support the old protocols then there's little incentive to upgrade.

If market share were more evenly distributed then individual client choices would have more impact since 1) it should be of less conesquence for any single client to drop support for an older protocol version 2) individual clients adopting the newer versions would make them more appealing 3) the combination of these effects *should* create a rolling incentive to keep close the the latest protocol because the further behind you get the less clients you can actually connect with.

Instead, all that matters today is that you support at least the oldest version geth supports.... So we kind of have to wait for geth to drop support for old versions before it even matters if we move forward.

author: pipermerriam
content: To be clear, this isn't a criticism of geth.  They are thankfully very conservative in their choices which occasional causes me mild frustration, but more importantly, they have maintained a very stable network largely on their own for a long time.  üíØ
